review.title: Strong Backdoors for Default Logic
review.abstract: In this paper, we introduce a notion of backdoors to Reiter's propositional default logic and study structural properties of it. Also we consider the problems of backdoor detection (parameterised by the solution size) as well as backdoor evaluation (parameterised by the size of the given backdoor), for various kinds of target classes (cnf, horn, krom, monotone, identity). We show that backdoor detection is fixed-parameter tractable for the considered target classes, and backdoor evaluation is either fixed-parameter tractable, in para-DP2 , or in para-NP, depending on the target class.

metadata.title: Strong Backdoors for Default Logic

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: It has become clear that this kind of reasoning is very different from the classical deductive reasoning that can be applied in practice, and can therefore significantly reduce the amount of deducible conclusions. In contrast, the behavior of people in the logic of thought and action is not so simple. In the 1980s, several types of formalisms were introduced that primarily relate to paraphrasing.

sections.heading: 2 Preliminaries
sections.text: We assume that familiarity with standard terms in computational complexity, complexity classes P and NP, and polynomial hierarchy (for more detailed information, refer to other standard sources [32, 20, 12]. sections.heading: 2.1 Default Logic
sections.text: We follow the terms of tab [34] and define a standard rule as a kind of triple rule: β = β = β (β = β). < < E is called a justification, and γ is called a conclusion. < E is set only if a standard rule applies. < W > Extension is stable only if a standard rule applies. < W > Extension is stable only if a standard rule applies. < W, D > Extension is stable only then. < W, D > Extension is stable only then. < W, D > Extension is not stable. < W, D > Extension is not explicitly class F, we assume that it is cnf.Definition 1. (Fixed point semantics, [34]).

sections.heading: 2.2 The Implication Problem
sections.text: The implication problem is an important (sub-) problem when arguing with standard theories. In the following, we first formally present the implication problem for classes of statement formulas and then give its (classical) implicit complexity for the classes Horn and Krom.Problem: Imp (F) Input: A set of F formulas and a formula. Question: Does? Beyersdorff et al. [2] have taken into account all Boolean fragments of Imp (F) and fully classified its computational complexity in terms of the frame of item Grids. However, Post's Grid only talks about limitations on the allowed Boolean functions. Since several subclasses of cnf, such as Horn or Krom, use Boolean functions, "¬" and "Auten," such classes are unlimited from the perspective of item Grids. Nevertheless, efficient algorithms for such classes of propositional satisfaction are known.

sections.heading: 3 Strong Backdoors
sections.text: In this section, we repeal the concept of backdoors into the world of standard logic. First, we check the backdoors from the starting position (42, 43), where a backdoor is a subset of variables of a given formula. (4) Formally, for a class F of formulas and a formula, a strong F backdoor is a set B of variables, so that for all mappings a set B of variables is considered true or false. However, the reasoning in standard logic has a ternary character. If we consider consistent stable extensions of a given standard theory, then one of the following three cases applies to a formula contained in relation to an extension E: (i), (ii) the negation is contained in E, or (iii).

sections.heading: 4 Backdoor Evaluation
sections.text: In this section, we examine the evaluation of strong backdoors for the extension problem in standard logic with respect to different classes of CNF formulas. < W > Standard Theory < W > Standard Theory < D > Standard Theory < D > Standard Theory < W, D > and a strong F ² test problem, which is a major task we must fulfill when using backdoors as our approach. < W > Standard Theory < D > Do we have a stable extension? < W > Standard Theory < W > Standard Theory < EC, whether we are studying the complexity of the "extension problem," which is a major task we must fulfill when using backdoors as our approach.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We found that the detection of backdoors for classes cnf, horn, krom, monoton and positive-unit is comprehensible by fixed parameters, while the classification is more complex for the evaluation. If cnf is the starting class and horn or krom is the target class, then the backdoor evaluation is in para-NP. If monoton is the target class, then the backdoor evaluation is in paraх p2, which can be solved by a fptalgorithm that can query a SAT solver multiple times [10]. If the target class is positive, the backdoor evaluation is tractable by fixed parameters. An interesting task for future research is to consider the rest Schaefer class [boefer], i.e. dualHorn, 1- and 0-valid, as well as the classes backdoor tractable.We have fixed parameters tractable.A interesting task for future research is to consider the rest Schaefer class [boefer class], i.e. Horn, 1-valid and 1-door, and backdoor.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: The first author is grateful for the support of the Austrian Science Fund (FWF), Grant Y698. He is also connected with the Institute of Computer Science and Computer Sciences of the University of Potsdam. The second and third author is grateful for the support of the German Research Foundation (DFG), Grant ME 4279 / 1-1. The authors thank Jonni Virtema for the reference to Lemma 1 and Sebastian Ordyniak for the discussion on Lemma 2.

In this paper, we focus on Reiter’s Default Logic (DL), which has been introduced in 1980 [34] and is one of the most fundamental formalism for modelling human-sense reasoning.

In 1992, Gottlob showed that many important decision problems, beyond the extension existence problem, of non-monotonic logics are complete for the second level of the polynomial hierarchy [22] and thus are of high intractability.
A prominent approach to understand the intractability of a problem is to use the framework of parameterised complexity, which was introduced by Downey and Fellows [12, 11].

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we introduce a notion of backdoors to Reiter’s propositional default logic and study structural properties of it. Also we consider the problems of backdoor detection (parameterised by the solution size) as well as backdoor evaluation (parameterised by the size of the given backdoor), for various kinds of target classes (cnf, horn, krom, monotone, positive-unit). We show that backdoor detection is fixed-parameter tractable for the considered target classes, and backdoor evaluation is either fixed-parameter tractable, in para-∆P2 , or in para-NP, depending on the target class.
